children.text: DA announces grand jury indictment of 15 street gang members
Judge allows quote wife made in murder case

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. -- An Albuquerque woman allegedly said "I wish I could kill him again" to a friend after her husband was gunned down in their own home nearly five years ago.  	Amy Herrera has been charged three times with murdering Air Force Maj. Marc Herrera, but the first two times the charges did not stick.  	Prosecutors want to be able to use that quote as evidence in Herrera's upcoming trial, and on Wednesday a judge agreed even after the defense said there was more to the story.  	There was a party at the Herrera's home. The guests were a group of UNM foreign exchange students. It was getting late. According to testimony in previous hearings, the students said Marc Herrera came home drunk, pointed a gun at them and left the room.  	Minutes later, they heard the gun go off and Herrera was dead.  	At first, Amy Herrera said it was suicide. But according to her lawyer, it was self-defense.  	Fast forward to Wednesday in court.  	"All I have pending before me is the defense's motion to exclude the alleged statement by the defendant and, I quote, 'I wish I could kill him again,' end quote," Judge Brett Lovelace said.  	Prosecutors said Amy Herrera said those exact words to an acquaintance about two weeks after her husband's death, but the defense said Herrera's words were taken out of context.  	"Ms. Herrera was going through credit card bills and some of her husband's documents after his death," the defense said. "She found credit card statements showing that he had been a member of AshleyMadison.com and other websites showing that he was either contemplating having a sexual extramarital affair or already having one."  	Amy Herrera's lawyer said that quote was immediately after she learned of this and she called her friend to vent and that she already admitted to killing him in self-defense to the grand jury under oath anyway.  	Prosecutors argued that all statements should be allowed into evidence considering the nature of the case.  	"Essentially in a murder case, any statement from the defendant where they admitted killing the decedent ought to be relevant for the trial on the murder," the prosecutor said.  	The judge agreed with the prosecution.  	Amy Herrera is charged with first-degree murder. Her trial is scheduled for the end of July.  	Prosecutors dismissed the first indictment in 2013. It was argued that two APD officers improperly demonstrated their version of the shooting before the grand jury.  	The second indictment was tossed as well after the state Supreme Court ruled the prosecution did not instruct the grand jury in a "fair and impartial manner." Whistleblower lawsuit filed over slain deputy investigation

LAS CRUCES, N.M. -- The retrial begins Monday for the former Santa Fe County deputy accused of shooting and killing a fellow deputy in a Las Cruces hotel.  	With the second trial slated soon, there has been a new whistleblower lawsuit filed over the case of Tai Chan. It comes from a Las Cruces detective claiming her supervisors deliberately obstructed her as she was investigating the case in 2014.  	Detective Irma Palos said that was retaliation for having previously reported sexual misconduct within her unit. Palos wants compensation for "emotional distress, lost employment benefits" and other damages. The city denies the allegations.  	  Click here to read the complaint filed against the City of Las Cruces    	  Click here to the city's response    	Chan's first trial in Las Cruces last year ended in a hung jury. (Copyright 2017 KOB-TV LLC, a Hubbard Broadcasting Company. All Rights Reserved.)
Roswell murder suspect extradited from Mexico

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. -- The Roswell man suspected of murdering his wife and four daughters last June has been extradited from Mexico, the U.S. Marshals Service and the New Mexico attorney general announced Wednesday.  	Police had issued a warrant for 34-year-old Juan David Villegas after  they found Villegas's wife and daughters dead in their Roswell home on June 11, 2016 . The girls were ages 14, 11, 7 and 3; the wife was around 35 years old.  	Villegas reportedly fled to Mexico after the murders.  	New Mexico law enforcement agencies asked the Marshals for help in finding Villegas, Marshal Conrad Candelaria said in a statement. They found Villegas in Sonora, Mexico and Mexican authorities apprehended him.  	Villegas was returned to the United States and Marshals turned him over to the Chavez County Sheriff's Office, Candelaria said.  	"With justice at hand, now our community can be one step closer to healing from this inconceivable act that struck at the core of the New Mexico community," he said.  	 Click here to read the grand jury indictment against Villegas on five counts of first-degree murder, among other charges .  	New Mexico Attorney Hector Balderas visited Mexico's attorney general, Raul Cervantes Andrade, to thank him for his country's assistance in apprehending Villegas, communications director James Hallinan said. A treaty between the United States and Mexico allows for the extradition of suspects in violent crimes and child abuse cases.  	"Today we begin the process of bringing justice against Juan David Villegas, who rocked the community of Roswell and the entire state when he allegedly murdered his own family and fled to Mexico," Balderas said. (Copyright 2017 KOB-TV LLC, a Hubbard Broadcasting Company. All Rights Reserved.)
